Award.AwardTitle: CREST-Postdoctoral Research Fellowship: Chemical Doping and Halogen Bonding Studies of Conjugated Polymers for Renewable Energies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Centers of Research Excellence in Science and Technology-Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (CREST-PRF) track within the CREST program supports beginning CREST Center investigators with significant potential and provides them with training and research experiences that will broaden perspectives, facilitate interdisciplinary interactions and establish them in positions of leadership within the scientific community. This CREST-PRF project is aligned with the research focus of the CREST Center for Renewable Energy and Advanced Materials (CREST-CREAM) at Norfolk State University (NSU). Compared to traditional inorganic semi-conducting materials, soft organic and polymeric semiconducting materials exhibit inherent advantages such as lower cost and less energy consumption on large scale manufacturing. However, the charge generation and transport mechanisms of soft materials are not quite clear and the conversion efficiencies of soft materials are still relatively low on average compared to typical inorganic semiconductors. The major goal of the proposed research is to enable a greater understanding of the fundamental scientific mechanisms and principles behind charge generations, charge transports, and morphological effects of soft organic and polymeric materials. Such research could lead to less expensive, lightweight, flexible, biocompatible, environmentally friendly, and higher performance alternatives to traditional inorganic semi-conducting materials and devices. These future materials/devices can contribute positively and critically to renewable and clean energy technologies, bio-technologies, health care, and therefore can contribute to a more sustainable human population growth.

The specific research objective of this project is to systematically investigate the effects of charge doping on the electronic, optoelectronic, thermoelectric, and morphological properties of conjugated or semiconducting polymers. In addition to traditional chemical/photo/electrode doping, a relatively novel concept of "halogen-bonding" doping will also be systematically investigated and evaluated as an alternative low-cost and convenient method of engineering charge generation, transport and morphological changes in soft organic/polymeric materials. Halogen bonding is a relatively weak bonding mode similar to hydrogen bonding and may be used to facilitate polymer self-assembly for increased solar cell and device performance. State-of-the-art techniques will be used to characterize potential changes in morphology and to test the final devices constructed from these engineered materials. This research is expected to generate new knowledge that will be widely disseminated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramElement.Text: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

ProgramReference.Text: CENTERS FOR RSCH EXCELL IN S&T

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT OF THE PROPOSED WORK

This project investigated the mechanisms and effects that doping has on the optoelectronic, thermoelectric, and morphological properties of organic/polymeric materials. This project sought to study the effects of doping on polymer semiconductors and if halogen bonding can be used as another method of controlling self-assembly. The results will also provide detailed information into mechanisms and details behind the effect doping has on material structure and if halogen bond doping is a feasible method to increase device performance. This project focused on solution-based doping due to the advantage of scalability versus other doping methods such as vapor doping. The scalability advantages that organic/polymeric semiconductors provide is the ease of mass production. Organic/polymeric semiconductor-based devices created using roll-to-roll printing, inkjet printing, etc. can be produced rapidly. For example, roll-to-roll processed organic photovoltaic (OPV) cells can be produced at the same rate that newspapers are printed. Vapor doping of roll-to-roll printed OPV cells would nearly be impossible considering the apparatus needed to conduct vapor doping. But solution doped OPVs can continue to be roll-to-roll processed the same as undoped solutions while being more efficient. Overall, solution-based doping is much less time-consuming and less expensive than modifying the host material during synthesis. Doping is usually associated with increasing charge carrier density, but in reality, doping can alter the host polymer?s structure. Halogen bond doping could be a promising means of increased self-assembly of polymers lead to increased device efficiency. The mechanisms and knowledge that was revealed from this research could open a new door and provide an additional means of nano-scale manipulation of morphology to researchers around the world. This will lead to more economical, higher performance organic/polymeric materials that can be used for multiple applications, including but not limited to solar cells, OLEDs/PLEDs, OFETs, and organic/polymeric thermoelectric devices.

BROADER IMPACT OF THE PROPOSED WORK

The results obtained from this research could lead to low-cost, lightweight and flexible alternatives to traditional inorganic materials and devices. Efficient materials and devices for renewable and clean energy conversion will lead to less CO2 emissions and reduced human dependence on fossil fuels that are already nearly depleted. The results were disseminated through publications and presentations at technical meetings such as the Materials Research Society (MRS) and NOBCChE to name a few. The PI prepared hands-on research activities with the aspiration to encourage and expose under-represented minority students to the world of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM).  The PI took on more than 10 students (undergraduate and high school) in which they conducted research, presented, and were assisted with choosing a major and applying to schools. All of the students that participated in this project were from underrepresented minority groups. This project produced eight publications and 19 technical presentations.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2020
Modified by: Harold O Lee
